messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Quasi-Linear Size PCPs with Small Soundness from HDX

Paper Abstract: Abstract We construct 2-query, quasi-linear sized probabilistically checkable proofs (PCPs) with arbitrarily small constant soundness, improving upon Dinur‚Äôs 2-query quasi-linear size PCPs with soundness 1‚àíŒ©‚Äã(1)1Œ©11-\Omega(1). As an immediate corollary, we get that under the exponential time hypothesis, for all Œµ>0ùúÄ0{\varepsilon}>0 no approximation algorithm for 333-SAT can obtain an approximation ratio of 7/8+Œµ78ùúÄ7/8+{\varepsilon} in time 2n/logC‚Å°nsuperscript2ùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëõ2^{n/\log^{C}n}, where Cùê∂C is a constant depending on ŒµùúÄ{\varepsilon}. Our result builds on a recent line of works showing the existence of linear sized direct product testers with small soundness [BM24, DD24a, BLM24, DD24b, DDL24]. The main new ingredient in our proof is a technique that embeds a given PCP construction into a PCP on a prescribed graph, provided that the latter is a graph underlying a sufficiently good high-dimensional expander. Towards this end, we use ideas from fault-tolerant distributed computing, and more precisely from the literature of the almost everywhere agreement problem [DPPU86, Upf92, CGO10, CGO12, JRV20]. We show that graphs underlying HDXs admit routing protocols that are tolerant to adversarial edge corruptions, and in doing so we also improve the state of the art in this line of work. Our PCP construction requires variants of the aforementioned direct product testers with poly-logarithmic degree. The existence and constructability of these variants is shown in an appendix by Zhiwei Yun.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Routing permutations on graphs via matchings",
        "Random sampling and approximation of MAX-CSP problems",
        "Improved analysis of higher order random walks and applications",
        "Proof verification and the hardness of approximation problems",
        "Probabilistic checking of proofs: A new characterization of np",
        "Checking computations in polylogarithmic time",
        "Robust PCPs of proximity, shorter PCPs, and applications to coding",
        "Subsampling mathematical relaxations and average-case complexity",
        "Constant degree direct product testers with small soundness",
        "Characterizing direct product testing via coboundary expansion",
        "Gap amplification fails below 1/2",
        "Robust locally testable codes and products of codes",
        "Improved fault tolerance and secure computation on sparse networks",
        "Edge fault tolerance on sparse networks",
        "Stability of homomorphisms, coverings and cocycles ii: Examples, applications and open problems",
        "Agreement testing theorems on layered set systems",
        "Agreement theorems for high dimensional expanders in the low acceptance regime: The role of covers",
        "Swap cosystolic expansion",
        "Low acceptance agreement tests via bounded-degree symplectic hdxs",
        "Locally testing direct product in the low error range",
        "Composition of low-error 2-query PCPs using decodable PCPs",
        "Chernoff bounds and reverse hypercontractivity on hdx",
        "The PCP theorem by gap amplification",
        "High dimensional expanders imply agreement expanders",
        "Derandomized parallel repetition via structured PCPs",
        "Fault tolerance in networks of bounded degree",
        "Assignment testers: Towards a combinatorial proof of the PCP theorem",
        "Approximating clique is almost np-complete",
        "Impossibility results for recycling random bits in two-prover proof systems",
        "A combinatorial consistency lemma with application to proving the PCP theorem",
        "Some optimal inapproximability results",
        "Parallel repetition: Simplification and the no-signaling case",
        "Lecture 9: PCP constructions via low degree polynomials",
        "Simple analysis of graph tests for linearity and PCP",
        "New direct-product testers and 2-query PCPs",
        "On the complexity of k-SAT",
        "Efficient constructions for almost-everywhere secure computation",
        "Hardness results for coloring 3-colorable 3-uniform hypergraphs",
        "Local-to-global agreement expansion via the variance method",
        "Ramanujan graphs",
        "Explicit constructions of Ramanujan complexes of type A~dsubscript~ùê¥ùëë\\tilde{A}_{d}",
        "Ramanujan complexes of type A~dsubscript~ùê¥ùëë\\tilde{A}_{d}",
        "Two query PCP with sub-constant error",
        "A no-go theorem for derandomized parallel repetition: Beyond Feige-Kilian",
        "Routing permutations on spectral expanders via matchings",
        "Nearly-linear size holographic proofs",
        "Parallel repetition in projection games and a concentration bound",
        "A parallel repetition theorem",
        "A sub-constant error-probability low-degree test, and a sub-constant error-probability PCP characterization of NP",
        "Entropy waves, the zig-zag graph product, and new constant-degree expanders and extractors",
        "Lecture 11: PCP and hardness of approximation",
        "Tolerating linear number of faults in networks of bounded degree"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Quasi-Linear Size PCPs with Small Soundness from HDX, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
